title: What will the Trump family do if Trump loses? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: There will be the ongoing tax thing and he would continue to snipe from the sidelines using Twitter. Maybe he can work on his wall as a privately funded project of which he is the leader. There will probably be a book of some sort. The Democrats would be wise to move on at this point. It was frightening when in 2016 debate Trump said he’d throw Hillary in jail and it would set a terrible precedent if the Dems are to dog Trump if he loses. I imagine some of his people already in trouble will be taken down and he will probably make use of the pardon if he is defeated. While Trump may be a super villian in the eyes of progressives and very bad at many important aspects of his job in the view of most Americans, it can’t be emohasized enough that most people live in political bubbles. If the polls are correct and it turns out 50%+ of country thinks Trump is incompetent and a majority of these voters think the GOP are idiot villains, it must pointed out that 40–45% think progressives and even moderate Democrats are the idiots who are acting in bad faith. One thing Trump has taught us is that each party is pretty much guaranteed 40% of the vote- the losers share of a landslide. If either Trump or Biden walked out in next debate (provided there is one) and said- “I was wrong. We were wrong. And we lied. And now it’s too late.” and then burst into tears they would still hit near that number. Missed Opportunity? This isn’t a popular opinion when visiting family in north suburbs of Chicago but the Democrats at the end of the day may have lucked out that someone like Trump was the first to really tap into the anger, disgust, contempt and dismay with which a near plurality of the country views the direction it is headed. MAGA Masks? A populist less inclined to alienate the hispanic vote for no discernible reason and who was ready to peddle MAGA Masks rather than MAGA hats and host social distance Covid Vigils rather than base rallies, and basically showed the empathy and determination that Bush showed in late 2001, would have been extremely difficult to defeat. He could still pursue the same Covid agenda and his calls to reopen economy would seem more credible. Every other aspect could remain the same. His democratic foes would be just as furious if he used PPEs to build his brand and there would still be no mask mandate- thus no freedoms curtailed- due to the 10th amendment. Next Act? At his age, there probably won’t be a second act. Presuming he loses, the GOP probably has to go back to drawing board. The base will make this a bit difficult and they will have to figure out a way to increase it a bit to drown out those voices. Eventually, they can try to get back to 2016 pre-Trump when they run candidates like Rubio and Jeb with the express purpose of peeling away Hispanic and Latino voters from the Democratic coalition. There is no magical merger between the interests of various groups, issues voters and racial groups. There is room on the left for a candidate who speaks to the working class of all races and is opposed to mere neo-liberal reordering where the 1% has the same advantages but happens to be slightly more diverse. I am not drawing a false equivalency between the current Democrat and Republican positions on issues like health care and entitlements. Just noting that the Democrats may have softer edges but there is a reason that the white working class abandoned the party in droves. There are myriad reasons why this is the case, but the “not voting their interests” argument is one I find to be particularly uninspired. You can find no shortage of pundits on the right claiming Black Americans don’t vote their interests and just as many left leaning journalists depicting less affluent conservatives as bamboozled bumpkins fueled by hate. I do not have the necessary level of hubris or experience to claim to be able to identify what any group’s best interests are and actually assume that they have a much better grip on what is important to them than I ever could (for obvious reasons). On the right, there is always room to critique the inefficiency of statist solutions and a party that has a taste for regulatory capture and is more than willing to let special interest groups dictate the choices and freedoms available to the lumpenproletariat (looking at you Michael Bloomberg- how many other members of the LGBTQ+ community do you plan on killing with your puritanical standards of nicotine abstinence and willingness to deprive marginalized groups of smoking alternatives like vaping.) So Much Winning? In the 2016 election, their House delegation received 1.5 million more votes than the Democrats. Compare this edge to Trump’s popular vote deficit and you see what an influence the Republican base has on their party’s politics. Because logically speaking, they dragged Trump across the finish. In 2018, under Trump’s leadership, their House candidates lost by a combined 9.5 million votes. Yes there have been midterm routs before. 1994 and 2010 were transformational rejections of liberal policies. But unlike those instances, voter turnout approached presidential election levels and thus makes it a much better indicator than say 2014, where the GOP won by a substantial margin but the total votes were 40 million to 35 million. 2016 US House vote totals GOP: 63,173,815 (49.1%) Dem: 61,776,514 (48%) 2018 US House vote totals Dem: 60,572,245 (53.4%) GOP: 50,861,979 (44.8%) 2020 US House Vote Totals? Average of generic ballot polls 10/7 GOP: 43% Dem: 48%

It depends on what route Democrats go. Route 1: The Constitutional Crisis  This would be the worst route but I think it is possible. The Democratic party is fueled largely by their hatred of all things Trump. I don’t mean they dislike him—they HATE him with every fiber of their being. They can’t even say Trump and instead say Dumpf, Benedict Donald, Con man, Treason Trump, etc. So the popular move with the Democratic party would be going after Trump and his family if they win the election. Appoint a federal prosecutor and pursue criminal charges or something like that. Note that this is not in regards to the recent tax trouble—that is a separate issue. Trump may be charged with a crime there and it would not be Biden coming after him. This is without precedent. It has never been done before and for good reason. Even after the Civil War, the leaders of the Confederacy were shown great leniency. There is a rule of sorts in politics and government. Anything you do or allow will be done against you. In 1975, Democrats lowered the number of Senators needed to approve an SC justice from 75 to 60. Republicans then lowered it 50. So let’s say Democrats move to charge Trump, his son, and his daughter with crimes. Even if there are no crimes, things can be invented—we are dealing with the US government where thousands have been convicted for crimes they didn't commit. So what happens? Well, if the Democrats win big enough, they will be able to convict at least a few in the Trump family of crimes. The case will likely end up before the Supreme Court, given its relevance, and maybe that will end with a conviction, maybe not. But a door will have been opened—one that can never be closed. First, this will enrage Republicans. If you are a Democrat, imagine how you’d feel if Obama and his family were charged with crimes and arrested by Trump and Republicans (using whatever mechanisms of government needed) during his first year in office. All hopes of reconciliation and unity will be forever lost—a line will have been crossed. Instead of just trying to beat opponents at the polls, we will use laws, prison, and the powers of government to defeat political opponents. When Republicans win in 2024 or 2028 they will win with a Trump-like candidate—someone that promises to punish Democrats. Biden and his family will be charged with crimes just like Trump. This will be the end of American republicanism. If you still want this outcome, than ask yourself why you're OK with permanently harming the US to attack a political opponent. Seriously, you likely think Trump is destroying democracy—so why are you OK with doing the same thing?  Route 2: Elder Statesman If Democrats chose to just move forward and not pursue charges, Trump will just become an elder statesman like many other Presidents. Trump has become the most significant force in the GOP since Reagan. That place of esteem will likely continue. He will return to his business empire and run things as he did before. Now he will be more famous and powerful than ever, though. I don’t think his empire will be better off with all this—certainly, he has created lots of opposition and anger and this may affect the bottom line. But Trump's primary real estate business will remain intact and worth billions and he will continue on running that company and hand it off to his children. Trump will appear from time to time in the news and in interviews—supporting candidates and Republican platforms. The GOP will move on as well. They never really liked Trump. He was not a very good team player to say the least and his outsider nature made him unpredictable. I hope this is the outcome, either now or in 2024 barring some horrible thing coming to light. Love or hate Trump, his time will be done—we all need to move on. In terms of damage to our systems, this is the best method to repair everything. Going after Trump and his family for revenge fixes literally nothing. You get your petty laughs and sense of superiority and you permanently make half the nation think of politics are war where human rights are secondary. Check out my space where we see both sides of the coin and examine the other side: The Same Coin

I think Trump himself will be in a Hell hole of legal and financial problems. Thanks to the NYT’s fine journalism, we now know that he owes hundreds of millions of dollars to foreign banks. Who does Trump owe hundreds of millions of dollars to?—most of it to Deutchebank (backed no doubt by the Russians—although we will not know that for sure until more investigation is done) Eric Trump Reportedly Bragged About Access to $100 Million in Russian Money. And repayment of these loans is guaranteed by him personally—meaning that HE is on the hook for them, not any business. He is not shielded from personal exposure. He will declare bankruptcy of course, and I think it’s going to go hard on him. He will have to liquidate some of his assets, or they will simply be seized. He’ll try to negotiate a favorable deal, but he won’t have as much leverage, and once he’s out of power, the Russians will no longer have any reason to bribe him given that he no longer has anything to give them. Furthermore, I’m willing to bet his legal costs are what my daughters would call “ginormous”. Think of all the lawsuits he tries to slap on to anyone who criticizes him. Think of all the NDAs he tries to get on anyone around him. And think of how many of those have been violated and how many people he sues. And how many contracts he has violated and how many suits have been launched against him. Think also of the State of New York prosecutors investigating and circling. After he no longer has the protection of the Office of the Presidency and his henchmen in William Barr and the Republicans in the Senate to protect him, here are some possible crimes it seems likely he will be prosecuted for: Obstruction of Justice, Campaign Finance Law violations, Tax Fraud, Money Laundering, Bribery. Some of these he’ll be able to settle with steep fines as he has done in the past, but I think prosecutors will be less willing to settle this time. There’s too much blood in the water. Trump has been an incredibly awful and divisive president, has done so much harm, hurt so many people, and made so many enemies. Payoffs are not going to be enough to save him. And Trump is terrible at business. He has no fucking clue how to run a business—except into the ground. He has been exposed. Even before he was president, no bank in the US would give him loans, and none will now either. His legal problems will consume his time and money. He will be hard pressed to maintain his lavish lifestyle. He’ll try to get a reality TV show, but I don’t think that will do enough. He’ll no longer be useful politically. I doubt he has any genuine friends—only henchmen, cult followers and people who saw him as a useful political tool. He’s become toxic, and no reputable network will want him around. He won’t make any more money off his name—tenants in buildings with his name are already petitioning their landlords to have his name removed. What about his family? Melania. We don’t know what sort of prenuptial agreement she has with Trump. I had heard that she recently renegotiated it. I hope for her sake she had wised up and gotten a better deal. She will try to separate her life as much as possible from his life, and focus on spending time with her parents and her son Barron, who Trump does not seem to care about. Possibly she has received a pay-off from Trump—but I think more likely it’s the promise of a pay-off. In which case she might lose everything too. Jared, Ivanka, Don Jr and Eric. I think they too, are looking at serious financial and legal issues, but just not nearly as bad as The Donald. Furthermore, he will probably pardon them on his way out (as well as try to self-pardon, but I don’t think that one will stick). They also might retreat to Jared’s family. Their future is not exactly bright, but not as grim as Donald’s. They are up to their eyeballs in Donald’s malfeasance. Barron. An innocent kid. Best case scenario is that he grows up to be a normal person, who eventually repudiate’s his father’s crimes and corruption. Worse case scenario is he grows into a clone of Donald Trump. Hopefully society will leave the kid alone to give him his best chance—but we don’t know much about him. What about Trump’s henchmen—like Guiliani and Bill Barr? They probably are not actually guilty of crimes that can be successfully prosecuted. Some of his henchmen might face legal charges—we’ll have to see what happens. Those who are guilty, and know they are, are probably expecting pardons in Trump’s last days. But it won’t surprise me if he doesn’t pardon them. His focus is entirely on himself, and I have seen that he won’t hesitate to throw henchmen under the bus once they are no longer useful. Loyalty is a one-way street with Donald Trump. Trump could be slammed with a pile of personal lawsuits once he leaves office. Here are 9 major ones he'll have to face. How Trump Could Be Prosecuted After the White House Former federal prosecutor: Trump could be indicted upon leaving office https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2020/07/10/supreme-court-vance-immunity/

Q: What will the Trump family do if Trump loses? As long as there is any loophole anywhere (a postal truck has an accident and the votes aren’t delivered by the deadline in the wrong state, or grandad forgot he already mailed his ballot in and somehow votes in person again, etc.), the Trumps will throw lawyers and $$ at the situation. They’ll never concede, which might not matter if court rulings over dozens of technicalities trump Trump - he might run out of squabbles. If the courts and Congress conflict, and Trump writes an (unconstitutional) Executive Order (which he has already gotten away with), will he call out the military to enforce it?(Example, delay the inauguration because the congress refuses to respect the court’s ruling). Will the military uphold their vow to the constitution, or will they violently clear peaceful protesters because their Commander in Chief told them too? Will the Supreme Court rule that the Executive can’t be over-ruled, or will they call him out? and if they call him out, will DT ignore them? (as he has done). There are constitutional lawyers who claim the Supreme Court has no more rights or responsibility for the Final Word on Constitutional Law than any other branch. If Biden wins the popular vote but not the electoral, or vice versa, he might fight tooth and nail, also. But he hasn’t shown any propensity for defiance of Supreme Court rulings, or deliberately antagonizing extremists to pull out their guns. Trump has no inhibitions about clashing to the point of war, and letting the Proud Boys know that It’s Time. Nov. 3 will not be a date of celebration, relief, or at least closure. Unless one or the other candidate overwhelms the vote, that date will only mark the beginning of a constitutional crisis, which could lead to civil war. Hitler and Mussolini crept into power by bending their foundational precepts, shouting down, suppressing, and then arresting those who stood up for Law. They sought “exceptions”, until, finally, their words were the only law, and millions of people began to die.

First I should say that I have read through several of the answers to the above question and am impressed with the depth of insight of. several authors. My answer will not be as long or as insightful. Those issues have been addressed by some posters with more eloquence than I could express. To disclose, I am a conservative registered Republican who supports Trump and intends to vote for him on Nov. 3rd. I do this more out of a fear of the Biden/Harris alternative than a love for Trump the man. I don’t know Trump the man, just Trump the man the media allows me to know. I’ve learned not to pay attention to what Trump says and to pay attention to what Trump does. Without going into detail he has done admirably well pre-covid although I’m probably in the minority. The majority of the “ruling class” sees him as a threat and therefore a dangerous man who won’t play by their rules. The “ruling class” is a powerful entity especially when coupled with their allies the mainstream media. The media shapes the opinion of the masses resulting in a whole bunch of people who hate Trump. To make matters worse Trump digs his own grave in his thin skinned personally insulting way. Un-Presidential as it were. Nonetheless Trump is infinitely much the better leader than way past his prime Biden. Pursuing an imprisoned Trump is out of order if only because it would only enrage the Republicans and incite them to return the favor in kind the first chance they got. Several posters mentioned that it would be the end of even the pretext of civility between the 2 Parties. I agree. Not only would government cease, but no sane person, except those in it for their own gain, would run for public office. Should Trump loose let him be. He’ll snipe from Twitter and wear the Republican hat of elder statesman (I use the word statesman loosely as Trump would have it) for a few years. The man is 74 so how long will he be with us? Besides, jailing a former US President is not the optic we want to portray to the rest of the world. Trump did rant often about jailing Miss Hillary but never did. Given what has come out recently a case could be made to that effect. The OP’s question is a speculative one. It speculates that President Trump may lose his re-election bid this November and thus is a hypothetical. As a hypothetical I found it difficult to address so the first paragraph of my answer is as factual as I could make it and only my second paragraph addresses the hypothetical. If President Trump wins re-election then the OP’s question becomes moot.

This is the trillion dollar question… Will Donald Trump concede power and have a transition or will he fight it? No ex-President has ever been charged with a crime (even ones that clearly committed a crime), BUT that comes with a huge caveat: no President has ever refused to accept the results of the election. If Trump leaves office—griping on Twitter a little bit but ultimately accepting defeat—I think he and his children will move on towards lucrative endeavors and becoming the full-time celebrities they always were. BUT, if he raises hell and tries to wreak havoc in the 75 (or so) days between the election and the inauguration… Well, that would be a different thing entirely. At that point, Democratic politicians may be forced to make an example out of him. Partly because they’ll need to discourage the next aspiring tyrant from attempting the same thing and partly because they’d be afraid Trump will actively foment insurrection/Civil War/violence if left unchecked. Hell, he already has done this towards Gretchen Whitmer and encouraging armed protests of state shutdowns and told the Proud Boys to “stand by” or go to the polls to monitor voting. I think the Democratic Party will only go after Trump if it becomes clear they have to because he’s either encouraging violent insurrection (“the people with the guns are on my side”) OR could defect to Russia, since Trump has also said he might “leave the country” if he loses. Keep in mind, that Trump is crazy. You don’t know if he’ll pardon his entire family and himself (which I could easily see) OR he’ll defect to Russia (which I could easily see) OR try to create an even more extreme version of Fox News (which I could easily see) OR call for Civil War OR die not long after the election OR he’ll just go back to promoting Trump steaks and have a life like Sarah Palin—part cultural grievance ambassador, and part celebrity-pitchman. The fact that all of these seem equally likely, tells you A LOT about Trump and his family, and what we’ve come to expect from them.

Melania will likely divorce him — she can barely stand to touch the man as it is, from the looks of it. Junior, Ivanka and Eric may face jail time, as would Jared Kushner, although I am not certain as they would all have the best laywers money can buy and may well get away with it all, as the rich and famous typically tend to do. Tiffany and Barron Trump, the youngest of the clan, are entirely uninvolved and will be fine. The ten Trump grandchildren, too, will be well provided for regardless of the election’s outcome.  The family does not strike me as particularly warm… or close-knit. Quite mercenary, in many ways. Although I am sure the affection the elder Trump children feel for their father-in-chief, is quite sincere. There may be some in-fighting, some blame being thrown around. But ultimately they will likely stick together, come what may. I can see Junior attempting to run for office at some point in the future, and failing miserably in the process, much to the amusement of the general public. I can also picture Melania, at some point after the divorce, contesting her confidentiality agreements and dropping a bombshell ‘tell all’ book to clear her name and condemn her former husband. Will make a shitload of money out of the deals it gives her.

I think it’s very possible he will more or less follow the trajectory of this man — the previous person that Paul Manafort managed to install in office for Vladimir Putin: Viktor Yanukovych - Wikipedia Yanukovych lives in Russia now. I can see Trump and all the Trumplings going to Russia to live, to avoid prosecution for their crimes. Maybe Putin will give Trump his own show on RT, or an even bigger media platform, from which to holler lies and harass and embarrass the United States. It’s probably Russia that Trump owes a lot of the $400 million to, so he’ll probably be inclined — even more than he is now — to do whatever Vlad wants. Their mutually beneficial arrangements can continue. Some people are worried that Trump and Jared will give away state secrets. But they already do that. Jared sends encrypted messages on WhatsApp, illegally, to various heads of state, like MBS. He was the one who proposed to Sergei Kislyak that the Trump White House and the Kremlin develop a backdoor communication system for secret/illegal conversations. Trump gave the Russians some really sensitive intelligence in the Oval Office, the day after he fired Comey over the “Russia thing,” which probably makes Israel and other countries reluctant to share intelligence with us — or at least to share it with our President. Whatever damage can be done, in terms of handing over state secrets, has probably already happened. So, as long as Trump doesn’t defect to Moscow while he’s still in office and take the nuclear football with him, we should fine. Heck, we can turn off the nuclear football if he does. And if he gives the Russians Air Force One, we can just build a bigger and better one. I’d actually be glad to see him move there. If I had enough PPE handy, I’d help him pack.

Many believe that Trump needs to remain as president so that creditors will hold off on demanding repayment. Creditors are unlikely to make demands against a sitting president, especially one who would not hesitate to abuse his power, via Barr, to retaliate & inflict harm on his perceived adversaries. Trump also needs a 2nd term so that the Putin Oligarchy will continue to support Trump financially in return for favors he provides them, including reduced sanctions, no retribution of Russian bounty on our soldiers, Russia free to control the Middle East, & Trump laundering Russian money thru Deutsche Bank. Trump power to support his Russian comrades subsides if he is no longer President. Trump has abused his power, via Barr as AG & GOP run Senate, to initiate investigations of Obama, Hillary, & other adversaries. The latest investigation of Obama found no wrongdoing. Question remains whether the next President, if a Democrat, should or would reciprocate by initiating investigations of Trump, including his taxes, fraud, abuse of power in office, & criminal dealings of quid pro quo that Trump initiated before & while in office. As stated, Trump will do whatever is possible to remain in office for a 2nd term to protect/enable himself financially & to avoid investigations that will likely expose his criminal history & fraudulent dealings. Unsure whether FOX will continue to support Trump or move on & not get entangled in Trump’s downfall. Trump is not above the law, even with his money, presidency, & the power that comes with that. Hopefully, the legal system will expose him & family & perhaps penalize them for their crimes, fraud, & abuse of power.

A lot of people assume that there will be anti Trump witch hunts. Much as some segments of the community might like to see that, I don’t think it is terribly likely. Generally speaking, there is no upside in wasting valuable political capital trying to put the boot in on a former President and his family when you still have to work with his party in politics. And there is also no need to pointlessly enrage and antagonise a section of the electorate who is already feeling sore about losing. I suspect that if he wins Biden will be very much the stateman, thank Trump for his service, and invite him back to the White House for the unveiling of his portrait in due course. I’d go further - I’d be quite shocked if that didn’t happen. So what will Trump do? He’ll almost certainly go back to what he does best - become a media personality. I suspect he will get an hourly slot on Fox News, or perhaps promote his own podcast or YouTube channel were he can still preach to - and, more importantly, receive the adulation of - the faithful, and he can rant on for hours about how he was the greatest President ever and how Biden cheated and it will all get lapped up by people in the country who love that stuff.

This is Sam Antar  The Antar family ran a New York City metro area electronics chain named “Crazy Eddies”. For the first half of its existence, it engaged in widespread tax fraud. In the second half of its existence, it engage in widespread securities fraud. Sam, who was a CPA, was instrumental in helping to make the books look right, especially for the second-rate auditors the chain hired. Among their primary strategies were to have few or no cash controls and fudging inventory counts. Anyway, the feds caught up with Crazy Eddies and started investigating. They had some pretty good evidence, but nothing definitive. However, Sam faced some pretty hefty jail time and made a deal to cooperate in exchange for serving no jail time. He lost his CPA license over the whole thing. Since then, he’s worked to train investigators in how to spot white-collar fraud. He maintains an excellent blog and web site. White Collar Fraud So, I’m guessing one of the Trump family is going to sing like a canary.

He’s screwed. He has no way to pay off his debts, he has shown he cannot operate a profitable business, he gave up The Apprentice his one successful venture. He goes bankrupt again and this time for real, but it won’t mean much he will have two things to fall back on. First By law, former presidents are entitled to a pension of about $220,000 per year (Melania gets another $20K), staff and office expenses, medical care or health insurance, and Secret Service protection. The pension begins immediately after departure from office. He gets to hire office staff up to about $100K per year at taxpayer expense. He gets free medical care in military hospitals only. He gets secret service protection for his lifetime and for his wife and for Barron until he's 16. Second, he will get housing, meals, clothing, medical care and security provided by the Federal Government at no cost once he is convicted of tax evasion and other criminal acts.

Biden has said already that, if elected, his DOJ will pursue investigations and indictments without any presidential interference. In other words, if his DOJ decides to investigate Trump, Trump family members, Barr, Giuliani, DeJoy and a host of other WH and GOP operatives, we will not know about it till the indictments come down. That being said, Trump may use his pardon power for all these individuals as he leaves the WH. BUT, he cannot pardon for state crimes. And you better believe that NY AG Letitia James and Manhattan DA Cyrus Vance, Jr. have been and are building their cases at this very moment. They may well be placed in handcuffs as they exit the WH. Given that they are considerable flight risks, they will most likely be detained with no bail. I don’t think it matters that Trump was a president. Remember, no one is above the law. The protection he enjoyed during his term ceases to exist. The crimes have been committed. So when the “chickens come home to roost” they will be confronted with the very unpleasant consequences of their actions and from which there is no escape. “The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice.” MLK, Jr.

What will the Trump family do if Trump loses? A lot was said, Not sure if it means anything, Other than most just bashing Trump. Some have no idea of what they're saying. Just repeating what they hear on CNN. But that's not the question. If Trump loses, Did you all forget that President Trump owned a sizeable business before becoming President. Let me assure you that the Trump family will be fine. And, all the Trump Haters can be happy with, becoming the next Socialize nation. Just like Russia, China, North Korea, Cuba. These far left wing nut cakes think that's the only way to go. My question is how come everyone in the world wants to come to America. President Trump is, the Man we need at this time. Don't turn your back on Freedom.

“What will the Trump family do if Trump loses?” Donald Trump asked the same question in front of a rally. His answer was, "Maybe I will have to leave the country." My guess is, he has already looked into where he can go into exile. Russia, perhaps? I don’t know if Putin would think he is much of an asset once he is no longer in power, though. As for the family? It's hard to say. Some might not feel so obligated as to follow him, no matter where he goes. The question to ask is what will happen to the family business once it is revealed how much it thrived at tax payers' expense while Trump has been president. In addition to losing the business that was tied to Trump's presidency, the law may come down hard on the Trumps with substantial fines, and maybe even put the Trump brand out of business.

It depends on two things. First, does the Trump family manage to hold on to the Republican Party? After all, they’ve taken it over and the Party’s voters mostly seem to belong to them rather than to the traditional Republican establishment. Could the Trumps turn the GOP into a radical-right family firm, like France’s Rassemblement National (formerly Front National). There might be a split, creating a three party system in America. I find it unimaginable that Trump would willingly give up his control of the party. Has he ever given away any of his property in the past? Second, if Trump manages to hold on to the party and his voters, despite being a loser, does he insist on running against Kamala in 2024, or does he allow Ivanka or Don Jr to be the next champion of the ordinary people against the corrupt establishment? If there’s a succession, will it go Game of Thrones? Will we see Putin lend Jared some GRU goons to spike Eric’s Red Bull with polonium?

What will the Trump family do if Trump loses? in the best of all possible worlds, the adults will spend the rest of their lives in prison, Melania’s citizenship will be revoked and she’ll be deported for immigration fraud (she worked while staying on a tourist visa) and Barron will go into the foster care system… … which would be better for him than being raised any longer by that clan of psychopaths.

They’ll have to find jobs because Biden will probably close down the country. Oh, wait … no, they’re successful business people, so they’ll be okay. But, people who already have been destroyed economically by the ridiculous “let’s make everyone stay home” solution will be in really dire straits if Biden has his way. Trump, and the nation, have found out that this is what happens when you follow the “science.” Next time, with, Trump, the vulnerable will be protected, and life will get back to normal for the vast majority of healthy Americans.

Well, since even the biggest lies and most outlandish lawyers they could come up with aren’t gonna save them from prison, the kids will try to flee to non-extradition nations. Maybe hang out with Eric Prince of Blackwater fame, Sec. of Ed. Betsy DeVoids brother. Dad will not be allowed to leave the country and will be detained for being an unacceptable national security risk if he were released into the wild. Before all that there may be a brief moment of ‘brown your britches’ fear upon confirmation of loss, but the moneys on them seeing what’s coming & already having an exit plan in place.

The smart ones (hehehehe, I know, I cannot believe I actually wrote that either) will leave the U.S. for someplace without extradition treaties with the U.S. Russia comes first to mind. The rest will spend whatever is left of Fred’s money on lawyers and accountants. Then, if they are able to avoid any real jail time, will likely put their names on a ghost written book or two, and then try to make a few bucks holding the same kind of Nuremberg rallies trump himself loves so much.

Hopefully, they’ll move on and enjoy their life. It’s what I would do. Keep in mind that none of them have to do this. They don’t need politics. They don’t need the government. They don’t need you.
